description: Students learn the most frequent, consistent consonants and all short vowels to enable CVC word formation. This foundational stage establishes letter-sound correspondence and basic decoding skills essential for reading development.
key_concept: Letters represent sounds. When we put consonant-vowel-consonant together, we can read and spell words. This is the foundation of all reading.
instructional_focus: Phonemic awareness integration with letters (not isolated)
Letter-sound correspondence mastery with orthographic mapping
Basic decoding skills through explicit systematic instruction
Systematic introduction by frequency and consistency (Adams, 1990)

science_of_reading_alignment.ehri_phase: Pre-alphabetic to Partial Alphabetic - children use first and last sounds in words
science_of_reading_alignment.national_reading_panel: Systematic phonics instruction most effective in kindergarten and first grade
science_of_reading_alignment.adams_principle: Most frequent, consistent consonants should be taught first
science_of_reading_alignment.dehaene_2024: Explicit instruction works; discovery learning for phonics does not work
science_of_reading_alignment.orthographic_mapping: Foundation for connecting letters to sounds in long-term memory

metadata.neurological_rationale: Most visible articulation enables orthographic mapping (Adams, 1990; Dehaene, 2024)

sound_of_day_integration.brain_science_connection: Your letterbox area is learning to recognize this letter pattern automatically
sound_of_day_integration.error_prevention: If confused with /n/, emphasize lips must close completely

teacher_tips: Watch for: Lips should fully close and vibrate for /m/
Cue: 'Close your lips like you're saying yum!'
Neurological note: This builds the visual-auditory connection in the letterbox area
Common error: Students may add vowel sound (/muh/ instead of /m/)
error_patterns: Substitution: /n/ for /m/ due to similar nasal quality
Visual: May confuse 'm' and 'w' due to similar shape

assessment_framework_enhanced.fluency_target: Contributes to 10 CVC words per minute by Phase 4
assessment_framework_enhanced.transfer_measure: Can use /m/ in novel CVC words not previously taught

research_attribution: Adams, M.J. (1990) - /m/ recommended as first phoneme due to visibility
Dehaene, S. (2024) - Visible articulation supports letterbox area development
National Reading Panel (2000) - Systematic introduction of consistent sounds

metadata.neurological_rationale: Clear vowel articulation enables CVC nucleus recognition (Dehaene, 2024)

decodable_sentences_98_percent: I am mad. (100% taught sounds)
Sam has a map. (98% - anticipates upcoming phonemes)
The mat is tan. (98% - 'the', 'is' sight words)

sound_of_day_integration.brain_science_connection: Short vowels create the nucleus of every syllable in your brain's reading networks
sound_of_day_integration.discrimination_practice: Contrast with other vowels as they're introduced

assessment_framework_enhanced.vowel_discrimination: 90% accuracy distinguishing from other short vowels

research_attribution: National Reading Panel (2000) - Short vowel instruction essential for CVC mastery
Adams, M.J. (1990) - /a/ recommended for clear articulation
Dehaene, S. (2024) - Vowel recognition supports syllable processing

metadata.neurological_rationale: Continuous sound facilitates blending in neural networks (NRP, 2000; Dehaene, 2024)

cumulative_decodable_sentences_98_percen: Sam has a mat. (98% - strategic phoneme anticipation)

sound_of_day_integration.brain_science_connection: Fricatives provide continuous sound for blending practice in neural pathways

assessment_framework_enhanced.blending_skill: Can blend CV and VC combinations fluently

research_attribution: Adams, M.J. (1990) - Fricatives provide excellent phonemic awareness practice

metadata.neurological_rationale: Stop consonants essential for word boundary awareness in neural processing (Adams, 1990)

research_attribution: Adams, M.J. (1990) - Stop consonants essential for word boundary awareness
